author: mrorange26

title: AutoX3D iPad 1 case with CAD file

description.text:
it is designed to be printed with 10% infill, 3 perimeter and 3 layers top and bottom.  Rectilinear or honeycomb pattern infill.  
This case has crush zones in the corners and if you print with the limited infill, it will serve as additional cushioning.   
The holes are for m6 bolts.  Im going to use hex head although allen head will work too.  
This is a work in progress and has  not yet been printed.  
I may be changing the file in the near future and adding the infill manually in the CAD file so that there will be  varying percentages of infill in different parts of the case.
I used a calipers, stainless ruler and my trusty iPad1 to measure and draw it.

author: largeformat3dprinter

title: Replacement knob for Einhell BT-SB 200 bandsaw
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a replacement knob for the Einhell BT-SB 200 bandsaw (see e.g. [Amazon]( http://www.amazon.co.uk/Einhell-Blue-BT-SB-200-Band/dp/B001EX6QAK/ref=cm_cr_pr_product_top)). This is quite a cheap bandsaw, but suitable for a small hobby wood shop. I broke the knob that raises and lowers the guide, but was able to design and print this replacement. It works very well, and is quite a bit stronger than the original! Attribution: I actually remixed this from a "generic" knob thing on thingiverse, but had to modify the scad file to allow for double cuts in the axis, and going "through" to allow the spring loading from the other side.
Pretty simple print, 0.3 layer, 15% infill PLA was strong enough for me.

comments.text: The taps are actually surprisingly nice, makes it much easier to make make fine/small adjustments, and, as you write, apply the proper amount of torque.
comments.author: madsdyd

comments.text: Nice remix, those tap arms were a bit of a gimick on the original, but they make great sense for a higher torque application like this. Cool!

title: Remote holder for bed
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a holder for a remote, that can hang on the edge of my bed. I have printed it to have a loose fit for a rather large Sony remote, but it will fit other remotes, I reckon.  
There are many other remote holders, but most are meant to be mounted on walls, or similar, while this one can hang on the edge of your bed.  
It can hold a remote up to approximately 55 mm (~2") in width, 30 mm (~1.25") thick, and about 250 mm (~10") high. The mount will fit bed walls up to 24 mm (~1").  
The source file is a FreeCAD file.
You will need to enable support for the hook to print properly. 0.3mm layer height 15% PLA was fine for me.

author: sagitaire12

title: Label Holder for Nespresso Capsule Holder

description.text:
This is an alteration of the Nespresso Capsule Holder to hold design labels for information on the capsules.  
If you love the design please like, collect and make it.  
Note: This part is not an official Nespresso part and does not stand in any relation to Nespresso.

Download the stl here plus the files at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:205728 to create the holder seen in the pictures. After printing I glued the capsule holders and the label holders to an acrylic plate, spray painted everything in matt black and added the printed labels. For one design I drilled holes and used screws to attach it to the wall, for my white design I used powerstrips to attach it to kitchen tiles. To design the labels to your needs: Measure the inner size of the label holder and create labels with capsule images and info on the coffee type. I used Photo Paper to print the labels on.

comments.text: Not quite, I left it there to be able to swap the labels in an easy way. Grabbing the label is easier that way. You can see that in the second picture: because of the opening you can get under the label.

description.text:
This is a "tool" to open a siemens washing machine pump house thingy.  
If it is stuck with grit, it becomes very hard to open. If you use a normal hand tool, there is a good chance you will ruin the handle on the open thingy. By using this, you avoid that.
You need to print it pretty solid to work, otherwise this key will snap. I used 1.6 wall thickness and 20% fill rate, 0.2 mm layer height.

title: Sink drain screw
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I have no idea what this is called in neither danish nor english. I made this for a friend, which lives in a house built by Swedes, with "swedish" sinks. For this type of sink, the drain plug is "connected" to a lever, that allows you to raise and lower the drain plug without getting your finges into the water, which is very convenient. However, the plastic part that works as the connection was broken on one of his sinks, and this is a replacement. Attribution: This uses the Thread library. Its included in the source.
You need to print it pretty solid to work, otherwise it will snap. Also, if it is very tight in the thread, try reducing the size when slicing, or reduce the thread radius in the SCAD file.

title: K40 Laser Cutter New Lens mount

description.text:
This was designed to replace the lens mount on the K40 "Cheap Chinese 40W CO2 laser engraver/cutter." With this, you can either install the original lens or swap in a diode laser mounted in the popular aluminum diode heatsink like the one in the photo from Victoryrush on ebay (where I purchased mine from.) The heatsink should be suitable for 1W or less diodes.  
Will work with either. The K40 lens tube is 15mm at the point it mounts in the holder. Between the fins of the aluminum diode heatsink, it is 15.5mm. I made it to be a little snug on the laser diode heatsink and the K40 lens screws together tightly. Both expect about 1.5-1.9mm thickness.  
You can also use the prongs to wire-tie (think bread tie) or wrap strong fishing line around them to secure the lens/diode if you are super paranoid. Not necessary though, it isn't going to go anywhere. :)  
Note: I have a 2W blue diode and the heatsink above is not adequeate enough for it. I have received a new heatsink which is larger. I will be posting up another design using that heatsink+fan soon.

comments.text: The problem with not having the central column is that if the drinker does not know how the cup is designed, they most certainly will spill all their drink. If the user brings the cup to the mouth with the internal pipe closest, the cup will empty. The reason for the central column is that when the cup is brought to the mouth the water level will not rise above the top of the internal pipe. The designer of the first cup probably had the tools to build the pipe in the walls of the cup but choose not to.  I designed my own column-less cup not thinking about this and learnt this the hard way.

title: TeleBall Arduino Retro Handheld Game Console

description.text: TeleBall is an Arduino based retro handheld game console. You cannot buy it. You need to build it by yourself. It lets you play BreakOut in single-player mode using one device and Tennis for Two in multi-player mode using two devices communicating via radio. 3D Print the case and the lid and then visit www.teleball.org for further instructions how to build it.

Building your own TeleBall device is a multi-discipline DIY project that can be done during one weekend, given that you have all the hardware parts available and some basic soldering equipment and skills. Building your own TeleBall is about:
  • 3D Printing
  • Electronics
  • Software Development
    • Depending on your choices when it comes to 3D printing, the PCB and the actual electronics parts, one device will cost you something between $100 and $150. The TeleBall GitHub Repository contains all necessary files, schematics and source code. Also have a look at the Detailed Project Documentation that helps you to successfully build your own TeleBall.

title: Emery cloth holder for ski and snowboards
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a holder for sandpaper designed to hold special "metal" sandpaper used to remove "grates" / "burrs" on steel edges of skis, prior to filing. In danish this is called "smergellærred", in english, I believe it is called "emery cloth". There are a number of ways to remove the burrs, which are often too hard to remove for the files. In my experience, emery cloth is the easiest to handle. What I have been doing until I printed this model was to put the emery cloth between my file and the edge, in order to maintain the 90 degree angle. However, it meant a lot of changing of the cloth. This holder is designed to allow you to use the entire width of the emery cloth strip, while maintaining a 90 degree angle to the metal edge. As you can see from the photos, I have tested this (on about 10 pairs of skis), and it works very well, and allows you to use the file for the finer work of filing/tuning the edge. Attribution: This uses the Thread library. Its included in the source.
Printed in 0.3mm layer height 15% PLA worked well. You should split the STL file in your slicer and place each part on the bed. You need support to print the biggest part.

title: Fan duct for Solidoodle4 w/ E3Dv6 and stock carriage

description.text: Provides a means to hold a 40x10 fan and direct cool(er) air directly around the nozzle to help reduce droops and increase overhang printing capability. I attached my E3Dv6 by removing the top lip on the E3d heatsink on a lathe at which point it slides right into the same hole the stock heater core attaches and is held with the same set screw. This fan shroud will not likely fit any other arrangement. Since upgrading my SD4 to a Lawsy carriage (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:104059) and stronger Y idlers (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:731769), my original design started bumping at the edges reducing the available bed space so I made a new "low profile" (_lp) version to address these issues and recover the full print volume.

You will need to acquire four M3x20 socket head screws and four M3X8. The fan on the left of the extruder is no longer needed so is a great candidate to use in the fan shroud. It must be removed from the extruder and sandwiched between partA and partB with the M3X20 screws. The whole assembly, then, is attached to the carriage with the M3x8 screws. I printed the lower shroud (part B) in Nylon since it has a higher melting point than ABS and PLA. My settings were: Part A ("_lp" version recommended):
material: ABS
nozzle diameter: 0.4mm
layer height: 0.2mm (built-in supports assume 0.2mm layer height - may not print well if other layer height is used)
supports: No Part B:
material: Taulman 645
nozzle diameter: 0.4mm
layer height: 0.15mm
supports: No After printing part A, remove any dropped loops that may interfere with the fan. You may need to drill the holes in the fan grills out with a 1/8" drill. DO NOT drill out the holes in the lower shroud (part B). Instead, tap them with a M3-0.5mm tap (chuck into a cordless drill for quick work). You may get away without pre-tapping but run the risk of splitting the part if you force the screws in. Although the shroud does not come into contact with the extruder or heater block, I still noticed some evidence of melting due to the close proximity but the air channel remained intact. Adding a layer of kapton between the heater core and the shroud seems to help. Unless you already have a similar fan in place, you are probably doomed to printing this twice. Once w/o the fan which should work but may not look too nice around the undercut areas and once again with the fan installed to get a cleaner print.

author: JONHPRUSO

description.text: My First attempt a Blender

title: Scope Rings, 1 Inch with Picatinny Rail Mount

description.text:
Since I had the rail, I felt like adding some rings. There are two sets of rings, a ~25mm size with two sets of machine screws, and a longer, ~35mm set with three sets of machine screws. I test fired these with my Hatsan 125 air rifle and it held up. I haven't gotten the check how well these will hold a zero yet. My first set seemed a little off centerline when I dropped the scope in, which is why I made the second, longer rings. Update 1/21/15:
  • New file added for my "zip grip" variant, which allows the use of zip ties instead of metal screws to afix the ring base to one of my rails that include slots for zip ties. I included a picture. Firing tests have had the rings hold up, but not the rails, at least when made from PLA. I would think that would mean ABS is a no go to. I plan on starting to figure out PET+ pretty soon, so I hope that will make these parts functional. If not, you can still use them to mack out your nerf guns and super soakers.

I print the rings laying down cross-wise and the cleat from the side.   
I used 6-32 machine screws for securing the top of the ring the base.  
The square rod with the threaded end, I have no idea what it is.  If you know, leave a comment,  I salvaged it from an old red dot scope I had laying around.  With that being said, a long thin machine screw and wing nut could to the same thing.

comments.text: Am I going to be able to use this on my nerf gun? I am converting it into a squirrel killa.
comments.author: D3DStudios

comments.text: Not sure, it depends on where you want to mount.  I have a few picitinny rail parts I designed on here.  If you can mount those, or even do a mash-up, then these rings definitely work.  It will work with any spec picitinny rail too.  The cool thing about printing your rails, especially with a nerf gun, makes it possible to glue the rails to the gun, not generally an option with real gunsmithing.
You should make one of these for weaver rails

comments.text: I just got me printer back online this week.  Last time I was test firing, the PLA rail split/delaminated while the rings held up.  I re-printed the rail at 200mil layer height with higher temp hot end and finished with some spray on lacquer, and that is holding up so far.  The rings themselves seem to have held out fine.  Hopefully this weekend I can get some sense whether this rig can hold any kind of zero.  My expectations are not super high, but then again, you never know until you try.

The current rail/rig I have is firing 6" right of target at 10m, so its almost so far off I would like to shim scope a bit.  In any event, I never intended to field PLA, so I am on hold until I can used to printing a more consistent material.  Basically I don't want to waste any ammo trying to zero and get groups at this point.

Customizable version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1002887 Want to use a glass plate on your print bed? Don't want to change printer settings to make that happen? Just put this shim on the print bed underneath the Z-axis trip-switch so that the trip-switch gets pressed one glass plate's thickness early. IMPORTANT: Make sure you read the Instructions under Thing Info! There is vital information there! If your printer is like mine, the printer prepares to print by (among other things) raising the print bed platform until it hits the trip-switch. The height it achieved at that point is its maximum height, from which layer height offsets—e.g., the first-layer offset—are subtracted. Inserting a shim under the trip-switch changes the maximum height my printer will arrive at. IMPORTANT: YMMV! Not all printers work the same way mine (PowerSpec Pro/Flashforge Creator Pro) does. If your printer ignores the shim and starts carving a path in the glass, stop the job immediately.

NOTE: Not all glass plates are the same thickness. I've deliberately left out the .stl file for this reason. See below. I'm using the glass from a 5×7" photo frame I bought at the dollar store; it's not quite as big as my print bed, but close enough. (And the size difference works out for other reasons.) The alternative would be to buy a custom-cut sheet of glass at OSH or someplace.
  • Measure your glass's thickness with a digital caliper.
  • Edit the .scad file and change the plate thickness to whatever you got from the caliper.
  • Generate your .stl file and print it.
  • Place the shim wherever it will hit the z-axis trip switch. On my printer, this is on the print bed platform, behind the print bed, just in front of the back wall of the printer.
  • Secure it. If you use tape, you may need to subtract the tape's thickness back in step 2. Don't skip this step—you don't want the shim to fall off the platform and into the guts of the printer!
    • What should happen is, with the shim in place, the shim will hit the trip-switch, and the printer will set the maximum height for that job to be that thickness lower than it would without the shim. You should then have a successful print on top of the glass. If your printer doesn't work like mine, doesn't have a z-axis trip-switch, or ignores the trip-switch measurement and goes by software or firmware settings, then this won't work for you.

title: Da Vinci Z-home replacement flag for E3D nozzle

description.text:
Update: I have since switched to the Bowden carriage for the E3d which allows the nozzle to be mounted at the original nozzle's height, so I no longer need to use this item.
Created in Tinkercad to lower the Z-home position of the Da Vinci 1.0 printer approximately 20mm.This reduces the chance of crashing into the E3d v6 nozzle.

Printed at .3mm height, 20% in-fill. After printing, just slip over the tab in the Z frame (2nd photo, triangle base to rear). Home the X and Y axis and then home the Z-axis . I wrapped the end in electrical tape and then snipped to fine tune the height rather than printing another one a mm longer. Calibrate manually and once you are satisfied, I recommend changing the eprom setting for the Z travel to the new lower maximum value to prevent inadvertently driving the Z-travel nut into the bottom of the printer. You may want to tape/glue the flag in place, but mine is just sitting over the tab and had been stable for over a week.

author: 118d

title: non-grinding feeder for Ultimaker
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This feeder can handle retractions with no problems and your filament will stop slipping or grinding. You do not need to use "proprietary" Ultimaker 2.85mm filament anymore as this feeder can handle 3mm and will not deform the filament. From now on you can use 3mm filament with the stock bowden and you will have no problems with jamming. OpenSCAD File is really ugly... needs a lot of cleanup... Update (2013-07-25):
The design has several problems:
  • Distance between gears is difficult to adjust.
  • Bolts get loose when retracting filament. I used loctite screwlock.
  • Rubber rollers were too soft and wear was too high. Replaced them by knurled steel rollers -> Maybe higher shore hardness rubber rollers would also do...
  • Added springs for better contact pressure.
  • Sometimes the variable part bends away and the gears jump over the teeth. -> Needs to be fixed by fixed by a guide on the left and right side or by a linear bearing.
  • The bowden clamp riser has a too big bore which leads to clinched filament if high pressure occurs. Don't know if this is really a problem because I used 2.2mm filament and had a clogged nozzle... -> fixed this by a aluminum part (see picture). Maybe we could also fix this by modifying the printed parts.s

You will need:
  • 14 bearings 618/6-2RS (6x13x5mm)
  • some screws, nuts, and washers (M3, M5, M6)
  • bowden clamp: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17027
  • rubber rollers
    I used these http://www.pollin.de/shop/dt/MTE0ODU1OTk-/Heimwerkerbedarf_Eisenwaren/Laufrollen_Raeder/Lauf_Transportrolle_17_mm_4_Stueck.html
    and cut a M6 thread into the hole. Maybe you can get some from an old printer or copier. It should also work with a knurled wheel. The deformation shold then still be less than with stock feeder as the pressure is much lower.
    • I printed the parts in PLA with 30% infill. Heatbed would be useful to prevent warping but it also worked without one. The bearing holes were a bit too large and I had to use epoxy glue to fill the space. I recommend to calibrate the printer.

Thanks to Rob and Tomaz for sharing their excellent models!

author: de_baseggio

description.text:
I always wanted a professional camera dolly to capture tracking shots, but couldn't rationalize spending the $$$ that most of the camera stores charge. So, I decided to print my own.  
The rails utilize some steel rods from a storage unit I'm no longer using. The only purchased parts were the mini-bearings and a cheap camera quick release attachment.

You'll need to modify the basic design to fit your particular rails and/or camera mount. Other than that, it's print, assemble, and use. The rollers include small plugs on the bottom for ease of printing. THe plugs pop out easily. Here's a short video covering the dolly design and usage process. There is also a short demonstration at the end of the video showing how well it works for tracking dolly shots: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WQOJunfnQPg The next step will be to add small cavities and o-rings to the rollers to reduce any noise created by the plastic rolling directly on the rails.

Just a holiday decoration.  Planning to attach it to my lanyard at work so I don't get the "you didn't wear green" jibing.   Made a second one at 50%, as the original size was just too much "Bling".  I'm sure you'll pick a better green.  I just used what I had on hand.

This is a replacement motor drive cogged belt for Sears Kenmore vacuum cleaner power head, Sears p/n 20-5285, "Power-Mate Vacuum Cleaner Belt". Also fits other similar vacuums, eg. Whirlpool. Can be also used as a generic cogged belt maker. I got tired of the belt in my vacuum cleaner power head breaking whenever it wrapped up something and having to run down to Sears for a new one, which was $7 and half the time they were sold out anyway. So I just made my own. This has been tested and somewhat to my surprise, actually works. I used Makergeeks' ecoFlex PLA (I have no connection to them other than as a customer). Other flexible filaments may work too. If you make this with something else, I'd love to hear about it. Note that NinjaFlex does not work - it's too stretchy. The Openscad source is included and it's fully parameterized so you can easily use this code to make your own cogged belt for any other purpose. Because flex-fliament can be tricky, I've included my printing recipe in the instructions. Just one thing - this is for non-commercial use only. If I see these appear on Ebay, I'm gonna be peeved. UPDATE: 1/22/15 Well it looks like I spoke too soon. My belt ran well for about an hour total use and then began to stretch out. So I guess while this design still works, it should only be considered an emergency replacement until you can get a new OEM belt. I will note that the official belts have nylon reinforcing threads in them, no doubt for the exact same reason. Bottom line, until we get an improved flex filament with better strength properties (or a way to embed reinforcing threads in the belts) this isn't a permanent fix.

comments.text:
Great work on this, very nice.
On your last update you mention that you need a way to include reinforcing threads. A dual extruder setup with nylon in the second head would allow circular bands to be created as part of the infill. The mix of extrusion temperatures could get interesting, but in theory at least reinforcing threads are a possibility...
comments.author: stapldm

comments.text: That is actually a brilliant idea.  At first I was going to say "but nylon doesn't stretch".  However, the reinforcing belts in the original piece don't stretch either, so I'd bet that this would actually work.  Unfortunately I only have a single extruder - but this is sure incentive for me to upgrade :-)
comments.author: stapldm

comments.text: Why couldn't we just make it bigger and use it for belt drives in 3d printers? RepRap, indeed!

comments.text: Exactly.  There is no reason why you couldn't make x or y axis belts with this stuff.  With my 8" bed, I can make belts as long a 8*pi, or 25".  That's long enough for the Printrbot.  One could make even longer belts by having the design snake back and forth across the bed, but then you'd have to change the code that adds the teeth since that is designed for a circular belt.

title: Rancilio Rocky Grinder Dome Cover Bean Rejector, Mark I

description.text:
The Rancilio Rocky is one of the better (well built but not insanely pricey) upscale home espresso grinders on the market.  It has at least one flaw, however: in the hopper is a dome-shaped plastic cap that helps guide beans into the grinder while protecting against the insane (attempting to insert fingers into hopper and grinding teeth while operating).  This dome cap is screwed in with 3 screws which also hold the hopper itself atop the top half of the adjustable burr grinder hardware, so these screw heads need to be accessible for cleaning by disassembling hopper from upper burr set every few months.  But the deep holes where the screws reside are JUST the right diameter for coffee beans (and not just peaberry, but any bean), so you end up with a few old stale beans residing therein.  
So, tired of having to either tweeze or use a screwdriver as an impact/drill to core these out, and get to the screw head, I came up with very simple friction-fit inserts to cover these holes. Now cleaning time is much easier.  (Even the 'quick clean' months - just dropping in Grindz or some similar burr cleaner - won't end up with crap in these holes.)

Parts couldn't be much simpler: cylinder with slight relief on bottom end for easy insertion.  Flat 'bladed' grip with a little concavity for better grasp.  Blend between the two for strength.  Single very small flat side - designed to be printed side-down for better strength.  Suggest using 100% infill.  Wouldn't want these to vibrate loose (if too light) and end up getting ground, although I made them long enough they shouldn't easily slip beneath the dome even if that were to happen.  As pictured were printed in clear ABS (although I don't keep my filament dry, so its kinda frosty with moisture-induced bubbles).

description.text: This modified LED cover for a gMax v1.0 extruder holds an Arctic S3 laser from Wicked Lasers.

No support is needed, but I suggest using a brim to print this model. The laser can be used with standard slicing software. The following settings will etch cardbard: etching speed = 5mm/s
travel spped = 50mm/s
nozzle width = 0.15mm
layer height = 0.15mm Layer height cannot be greater than nozzle width You only want one slice in gcode, so object height should be arround 0.2mm. A Z-height of 25mm is the optimal focal length for this laser/lens. Generate your gcode first, and then manually edit the gcode to use the correct height setting. Find/Replace all "G1 Z0.1500" command with "G1 Z25".

text = Twaffic.net

This design is for a small turning knob for a 3/4 inch bolt. It is small enough to fit into tight spaces and is open to allow bolt to travel through. The bolt has to be press fit into the plastic. I use a blow torch and quickly the nut, then press it into the plastic for a tight fit.

The design was deliberately made tight. Once complete, heat the bolt and press fit it into the piece. Using a blow torch, I place the bolt over the flame for about 2 seconds, then press it down. Make sure your alignment is correct before you press it down and cool it quickly (run it under the tap).

title: Universal Microscope and Telescope camera Mount for phone or camera

description.text:
This is a modification of the item 59344 posted by cswaim The revisions are as follows:
  • Extended the center slide so it is easier to put phone in and out of the phone holder.
  • Modified the clip shape and length to give a more solid grip on the site bore.
  • Added a rubber washer to remove the slop out of the bushing fit to the clip and slide holder. (This requires an extra part from your hardware store, which is not listed in CSWAIM design

I printed 10% fill 300 micron resolution with no rafts. I have included one file laid out for the Maker-bot if you want to save some time, and print all pieces in one printing.   
The parts list is the same as specified by thing 59344 with the addtion of a 3 mm rubber spacer for the bushing.   
Parts List: Qty 6: 4-40 x 1/2 Socket Head Cap Screw (McMaster 92196A110) Qty 1: 2.5" x 1/4" OD Spring (McMaster 9657K171) Qty 1: 1/4" x 1-3/8" Clevis Pin (McMaster 97245A242) Qty 1: 1/16" Cotter Pin (McMaster 98335A044) Qty 1: .56" Dia x .063" wire x 120 deg Torsion Spring (McMaster 9271K641)  
To assemble:  
1) Screw the left cap onto the left slide and the right cap onto the right slide. It really helps to start the screws a few turns in each of the holes first then take them back out and assemble the two parts.  
2) The recess down the center of the right slide has to fit over the square piece of material underneath the left slide. After the right slide is over the square piece of material the two pieces can slide together.  
3) Feed the spring through the hole in the bottom of the right slide (BE CAREFUL! Wear some glasses so the spring doesn't shoot out and hit you in the eye!! You think it won't happen, but it will)  
4) Load the clevis pin through the bushing then screw the bushing to the bottom of the right slide.  
5) Next put the 2 clips together to install the torsion spring.  
6) This is by far the most difficult part of the assy process and once again, BE CAREFUL! Wear some glasses so the spring doesn't shoot out and hit you in the eye!! You think it won't happen, but it will... (Using a pair of leather gloves,Squeeze the long arms of the torsion spring together and place a zip tie around them to hold set, and insert inside the back of the clips (it way help to wear some time of gloves because the ends of the springs can be sharp). While you are still holding the ends of the spring, take the slide assembly and place the clevis pin through the larger hole on the top side of the clips, thru the spring and thru the small hole on the bottom side of the clips.  
7) Once the clevis pin is thru the bottom hole of the clip then put the cotter pin thru the small hole at the end of the clevis pin.  
8) You will need to trim the ends of the spring with a diagonal cutter. Trim them short enough that you will not cut yourself on the trimmed ends when using the device.  
One thing to note is that these holes were sized to work well on my printer . You may need to make the holes larger if the resolution on your printer is different. The clips should move very smoothly otherwise they will not grip the eyepiece very well. These were printed on a printer with support but were designed to work on a printer without support. Let me know if there are any issues.

This is a case in 3 parts (top, bottom, push-button) for the Mobilinkd TNC2.  It is very similar to the TNC1 case.  The only difference is that the side opening for the slide switch has been removed.  The TNC2 no longer uses a slide switch to set the PTT style.

Note: As with the TNC1 case, the tolerances are pretty tight. You will need to scale the model to account for any shrinkage (typically around 0.5% for ABS or HIPS). Otherwise the screw holes will not line up with the PCB. If the TNC will be used in a motor vehicle, ABS is recommended to withstand the summer heat. The case is designed to be held together with 4 #1x3/8" (SAE) or M2x9.5mm (metric) self-tapping screws. M2x8mm should work as well.

title: Tool Holder for UP Plus 2 3D Printer

description.text:
My first build project using FreeCAD. Keeps my two most used tools
close to my 3D printer. Two strips of Velcro keep it attached.
Note: The holder matches the width of the pillar,
so take care when mounting to keep it clear of the moving platform.
FreeCAD file is included for those interested, it's messy (my first) so
I'm open to tips from you more experienced makers. Enjoy!

Built as an exercise to help me decide which 3D modeling package
to lock in on.
I tried Blender (overkill for simple but precise modeling),
Openscad (liked almost as much as FreeCAD),
123Design and others.
I settled on FreeCAD and it seems to fit my needs best. I made some measurements of the two tools I use the most
and just started designing. It's simple, visualize what you want,
and start building your part using primitives and Boolean operations
to create, well, anything you can imagine. Be sure to merge all your parts into one part before exporting as a mesh file (stl). Load into
your printer app (3D Print in my case), position it on it's back using "place" and Print. Modify, improve, make it your own.

title: cOssel Bowden Extruder - Geared Stepper - v2

description.text: Detailed description/instructions: http://cdaringe.net/cossel-bowden-extruder-v2/ A bowden-type extruder designed as a drop in replacement for other popular bowden designs, such as Airtripper's v3 or bsp, but tailored specifically for using a geared stepper motor. Integrated geared steppers have a different mounting hole pattern than traditional NEMA 17 motors. A popular geared stepper motor in the RepRap domain is the Phidgets 5.18:1 (1, 2) motor, which I have used as a reference in the design. The motor mounting holes are much closer to one another than on a traditional motor, forcing the extruder body to be more compact than it's non-geared counter-parts. Only a 1.75mm filament is uploaded at the moment, but if there is demand, I can upload a 3mm version. Of course, you can simply drill the guide holes out to accommodate.
Please visit http://cdaringe.net/cossel-bowden-extruder-v2/ for complete build instructions!

comments.text: I'll look into those things.  I think I'll print up your extruder!  I am running a 5:1 planetary gear system in front of the stepper.  I got different filament and, guess what, much better!  I"m using filament from Push Plastic.  It works quite well.
comments.author: reef1944

comments.text:
hey reef:
bummer! with the bowden tube disconnected and idler loose, is it low resistance pushing filament through the full extruder body? If your bowden fitting is not co-axial with the filament thru-hole, I can see this happening. Make sure the filament and filament travel paths are all coaxial thru the extruder. If the filament is breaking otherwise, it's not likely in the extruder, but perhaps resistance in the tube or an issue in the hotend. ensure the correct thermistor is configured/good connection/etc. Also, if you drive gear is much larger diameter for some reason, that could cause it! My filament when pushed thru the extruder just gently rests in the drive gear groove.

remixed_from.author: coberdas
remixed_from.title: Replace your Roller Bearings with Bronze Bushings on your CTC printer

title: Bronze Bushing Upgrade for Flashforge Creator

description.text:
Because I've been taught to define acronyms: I.D. = Inner Diameter
O.D. = Outer Diameter This is a spacer needed to install standard 14mm O.D. X 8mm I.D. Bronze Bushings onto the FlashForge Creator. The stock LM8UU Linear Bearings have an outer diameter of 15mm. Standard Bronze Bushings do not come in a 15mm outer diameter size (I haven't found any at least). After doing this upgrade my printer runs MUCH smoother and quieter. It also feels much stiffer than it did with the stock linear bearings. Printer runs like butter now.

• You will need (12) Bronze Bushings to swap out all of your stock linear bearings. I got mine from http://www.sdp-si.com/. Pretty fast shipping. Size is 8mm I.D. X 14mm O.D. X 16mm Long.
    • Bronze Bushing Part Number (from sdp-si): A7B4MP081416

  • Print out the spacers. I printed out a few extra (sixteen total) just in case. You'll noticed that the spacer I.D. is a little bigger than 14mm. I designed it like this so they can be pressed in easily but still fit snug (they fit perfectly). The uploaded .x3g file was generated in Makerware (my Simplify3D doesn't like thin walls) but feel free to slice the stl however you like.

  • Press the spacers (carefully!) onto the bronze bushings.

  • Remove your extruder head.

  • Disconnect the connector going to the X-axis motor and the connector going to the X-axis switch. Carefully move them out of the way.

  • Disassemble the Y-axis Rods. Slide the bearing holders (plastic pieces) off of the Y-axis rods. Slide the extruder carriage off of the X-axis rods.

  • Remove the the old bearings from the Y-axis holders and the extruder carriage (total of eight bearings at this point). I used an Allen key to help pry them out. Be carefully doing this so you don't crack your plastic.

  • Remove your build-plate arms and carefully pry out the old linear bearings. At this point all twelve of your old linear bearings should be removed.

  • Press the new Bronze Bushings w/ the 1mm Spacers (installed in step 3) into all locations where linear bearings were. Total of 12.

  • Put everything back together in reverse order.
    • Notes:
    I noticed that the bushings and X/Y axis rods were binding just a little when I tried sliding the extruder carriage in the X and Y directions. This was probably from the bushings not being installed perfectly inline. This however made no difference and the printer runs like butter. I found it impossible to install the belt spring-clips once the belts were already installed onto the pulleys. Instead I put the spring clips onto the belts first and then installed the belts. I made sure to "tension" the belts enough so the spring clips were engaging.

A 2-part partial enclosure for a PSU with holes for IEC 14 AC and XLR DC connectors. Update
STL included for both 100x50mm and 114x50mm.
OpenSCAD files can be easily configured to support any size.
Removed unprintable corner of front legs from the back.

The parts are designed for a 50x114mm PSU (360W) -http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/UK-Stock-DC-12-24V-Universal-Regulated-Switching-Power-Supply-for-LED-Strip-CCTV-/151123354933
The openscad files can be easily adjusted to support other formats. The back part provides holes for:
  • XLR DC connector - http://uk.rs-online.com/web/p/xlr-connectors/0457954/
  • IEC AC connector - http://uk.rs-online.com/web/p/iec-connectors/2615878/ (mounted with 2x3.5mm screws)

The STL files provided are for 114x50mm and 100x50mm variants and include 0.5mm padding making a total height of 50.5mm for easier insertion. The thickness of the walls, height of legs and many other parameters can also be updated easily.

description.text: This is an outdated (but still playable using Third Edition rules) version of Pocket-Tactics. For the new (and much improved) Fourth Edition sets and pieces, check out this collection. We'll be updating the new edition to include rules for all of the Third Edition units, so if you have printed them (or want to), check in for updates and eventually all of those pieces' rules will be available. We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...) Enjoy! This force was co-created by fellow Ill Gotten Gamer, Dan Pettit.

description.text: This is my attempt to create a bowden mount for my e3d v6 hotend. This is untested, and likely has many bugs since its my first attempt at a complex model. I would strongly advise you to wait on printing this one... Update 1/5/2015 - Printed v1 with no issues, noticed the hotend can be moved ~7mm closer to the mounting plate, and updated design to reflect this. Have not test fitted extruder yet, and will do so prior to printing this version. V1.1 is attached, cad screenshot attached, plus photo of v1 post printing. Update 1/5/2015 part deux - uploaded 1.2, which is a much lighter weight version, the original source file was very beefy, I believe unnecessarily. I also test fit the hot end, the e3d v6 fits very tight and the m3 bolts lock it in really nicely, It needs to have the hot end raised 22mm, so 1.3 will address this, and I'll print and mount that along with my extruder when that's ready. ... I got carried away and did this change, so you will see 1.3 attached. It is slightly more than a 22mm raise, to clear the mounting bolts, so I'll see how this works, and if a nice side effect is a couple mm of Z... Update 1/12/2015 - Printed the latest version, and things look promising with it. Waiting on myself to finish the cold end so i can test fit everything without breaking down my printer multiple times. Time has been very limited due to extreme cold causing car problems (first world EV problems :/). Credit: I used the printrbot bowden model as a basis to start modelling this, so credit is given to the original designer.

My Aviators never quite fit properly behind my ears, so this is my solution for a more comfortable fit. You can easily make your own for any type of wireframe glasses or sunnies (best for wire arms with a diameter of 1.5mm, although you could scale the print or simply drill the holes out to fit your frames). Simply cut the arms off, leaving 15mm of length to slot into the holes of the new 3D printed arms. I used Araldite to glue them into place. Make sure you try them on before gluing, you want to get a good angle on the arms so that they wrap around your head behind your ear. For full details and images of how I made this item just visit my blog https://edditiveblog.wordpress.com/2015/01/05/3d-printed-arms-for-sunglasses/
This design prints completely without support, and it comes off of the print bed - with spinning wheels.
Printed at 0.2mm resolution with 10-15% Infill. Print the Hummer without raft or support.

title: Macro lens adapters for Nikon F-mount

description.text:
Look at those two sample pictures! Wow! You can now give any Nikon F-mount lenses or adapters a super macro super power! UPDATE: Added a new retention ring for lens-side mounting. No tools or rubber bands needed! Just snap it onto any macro adapter and check that its protruding tip meshes with the cosponsoring locking hole on your lens. I put two to a plate so printers will have time to let the previous layers cool when it comes to printing the thin locking nib. UPDATE 2: Strengthened retention ring for lens-side mounting. In Use:
The two sample pictures were taken with a 40mm and 80mm printed adapter stacked on top of each other with a Minolta 50mm F/2 lens and lens-less F-mount to MD/SR-mount converter. No cropping was done. (minimum focal distance for this setup is roughly 65mm or 2.5in) The demo video titled "Tiny things on a 3D printer" was recorded with an 80mm printed adapter (predecessor version; see below) and Minolta 50mm F/2. http://youtu.be/D8-BCeOGRiQ Locking example video (see Instructions) was recorded with 20mm printed adapter and a Nikkor 35mm F/1.8. Features:
1) Built-in tab opens aperture all the way on Nikkor lenses that do not have manual aperture control. This tab can be broken off or shortened if desired. (see "d" in the Instructions for more control options) 2) These are designed to mesh precisely with the locks on both the camera body and lens for safe use. (lens-side lock pin requires rubber band Lens-side requires new C-clip) 3) Lenses remain in the same orientation as they would without these adapters (name-plates up). 4) Three sizes are provided; 20mm, 40mm, and 80mm. 5) You can stack them. 6) These may be printed without support, though the aperture tab may fail to function fully. See Instructions for more tips. Also check out my F to SR-mount macro adapter, the predecessor to this design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:619663

Tips:
a) Start small (20mm). Not all lenses work well with the larger adapters. You'll still be surprised with the results. b) These are perfect for use with other mount-type conversion adapters and old or fast lenses with full manual control. c) A lens-lock key is provided separate from the main models. Use a rubber band to keep it from falling out. To use these locks, watch this video. http://youtu.be/F9BbPP3m9OI Use the newer C-clips to lock your lenses. See second picture above. d) You can achieve manual control with Nikkor lenses that do not have a manual aperture ring by omitting the lens-side lock and turning the lens body within its mount.

Crystalux is a light composed of crystal-shaped modules, which can be connected with each other via magnetic joints. A battery provides the electricity, the magnets lead the current through the structure. Each module can be attached in six different angles, which allows a wide range of possible sculptures. When connected, the modules illuminate from whithin.

You need:
  • white filament for 3D-Printer (colored filaments might be less translucent)
  • acrylic glass (2mm thickness)
  • 2m of thin electric cable
  • 20 white LEDs
  • 18 round magnets (diameter 4mm, height around 7mm)
  • 18 round magnets (diameter 3mm, height around 6mm)
  • 9 whashers (diameter 13/24 mm)
  • thin foam rubber
  • 1 coin battery (3V)
  • superglue
    • the kit is supposed to include 10 modules. Four with parallel top and bottom surface, six with opposed top and bottom (two of them are the start and end modules)
    the mantle is 3D-printed, the caps where the magnets and LEDs are sticked are composed of several pieces of plexiglass, cut by laser cutter.
    If your printer closes the top or bottom, cut it open carefully (except at the start and end module) and use the smallest possible wall thickness to guarantee translucency.
    Cut the pieces of plexiglass and glue them together as indicated in the file. Make sure the holes fit exactly, otherwise you wonâ€™t be able to put the magnets afterwards. Now cut the cable into pieces of about 9 cm and strip them at each end. Upper cap
    As soon as the glue has dried, put the magnets, LEDâ€™s and cables into the appropriate wholes. Make an attempt first and cut the wires of the LEDs at the right length. Important: Make sure that the positive pole of the LED is always in the centre of the cap, the negative pole you put at the outer hole. After plugging in magnet, LED and cable they should already hold quite tight. Put some glue into the hole, not too much, otherwise it will disturb the electric contact. All the magnets should be on the same level at the outer side of the cap, they should stick out about 1 millimeter. The magnets have to be put always in the same direction (as far as the polarisation is concerned), so each module can be connected with any other one. Itâ€™s ideal to put the bigger magnets with the positive pole upwards and the smaller with the negative pole upwards. The modules will centre on their own when being connected. Lower cap
    The piece which is surrounding the washer is quite fragile, so be careful. Put the magnet, LED and cables, then put a rubber ring and a washer in the track provided. Make sure about the electric contact and controle it from time to time, also at the upper cap. Finally put some glue to fix everything. Finally put this object into the mantle and attach it with superglue. Use only little glue at the first module, which contains the battery, so you can open it again and power off the light. The first and last module are special anyway, take a look at the file. There you go, connect the modules and hope thereâ€™s no loose contact. To be honest I had to put some conductive paint on the magnets and washers, because the contact wasnâ€™t always ensured. Anyway: If this instruction sounded a bit complicated to you, thatâ€™s quite how it was to develop this thing. So itâ€™s still more like a prototype than a finished product, that has still to be completed. By you maybe!? Created by Fabio Kunz in FabLab Zurich
    Thanks to the FabLab staff and to Christoph Laib for financial and technical support.

title: Modified Bowden Locking Clamp Clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This part is based on Jeroen van Zijp's "Bowden Locking Clamp Clip" with modifications to improve fitment and ease of use.
Description
This part is based on Jeroen van Zijp's "Bowden Locking Clamp Clip" (https://www.youmagine.com/designs/bowden-locking-clamp-clip). I specifically selected the 1.5MM version and made two modifications:

  • I created a slight sweep up to make it easier to get under the connector.

  • I cut a slice out of the vertical cylinder to give it enough flex to get on but still hold tight.

I successfully printed this on the Ultimaker 2 with:
  • Form Fortura PLA
  • 210C Head Temp
  • 70C Bed Temp
  • 0.1mm Layer Resolution
  • 100% Infill
  • 50mm/s

title: Capacitor Discharge Tool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text: Safely Short-Out Air Conditioning Capacitors- Read Instructions

I needed a small enclosure that had two holes in the ends that I could make a capactior de-energizer for my tool kit to discharge air conditioning capacitors. Once printed, Do not pry it off your heat bed. Let it cool until it naturally pops off as not to bend the ABS as the lid might not fit. Allow plently of time for the project to cool down then pre-fit the lid and using a sanding sponge or the like, sand down all the edges until they are all smooth. Clip your dual clip alligator lead in half, insert them though the holes. Strip the wire and solder the resistor to the leads. Once cool, feed the wires back though the holes and fit the resistor in the box as shown in the photograph. You can apply super-glue, liqiud electrical tape or silicone to hold it into place in the enclosure and also apply a generous amount to the wires and holes to prevent wire movement once it dries. Correctly orientate and apply glue to the lid and snap it into place. Let the glue dry and your done. A good dose of liquid electrical tape over the entire box and a little ways up to wiring make for a good non-conductive watertight test instrument. I have found plenty of uses for this little box.
  • DC lov voltage wiring connections junction box. (splices)
  • Mounting for indicator bulbs needing a see though diffuser. (use transparent ABS)
  • Mounting of mercury and reed switches.
  • Cartridge type glass fuse holder.
    • Project print size: 94.15 x 15.52 x 11.54 P.S. If you need a Microwave Oven capacitor shorting instrument, subsititute a 1K to 20K Ohm ceramic resistor (5, 10 or higher wattage) These can be round or square. description.text:
This vase was created entirely to test Simplify3D's "vase mode" feature: It prints the walls as one contiguous corkscrew spiral. Turned out great.
Modeled in Maya.
The image with the light on top is a combination with my Light Orb 01 print.

Sliced in Simplify3D, printed on Makerbot Replicator (1) with these settings:
  • Natural PLA @ 200 deg. HBP off.
  • 3 bottom layers, no roof, no infill.
  • 200 micron layer height.
  • Enabled "Single outline corkscrew printing mode (vase mode)" : 1 shell.
  • 90mmsec print, 120mmsec travel.
    Took exactly 3 hours, 2 min.

I had clearance problems with the rails used to mount the Rambo board in the MendelMax 3.0 kit. So I created the mounting parts, shown in yellow in the photo, that provide a much better fit. The top extension adds 1 cm reach so the mounting rail doesn't hit against the Y stepper motor mount. I created slots in this part so you don't have to get them mounted perfectly.

Print two of each part. You'll also need the following:
  • 4 M3 x 16 screws
  • 6 M3 nuts
  • 4 M3 x 8 screws
    • Insert two M3 nuts into the back of each Rambo Nut Retainer part. Then use two M3 x 8 screws to attach these to the top rail, as shown in the photo. Use the M3 x 16 screws and nuts to attach the Rambo board to the slots in Rambo Post part, and also using the Rambo Standoff parts for the bottom rail.

title: Laser Etched LED Quote with Printed Base
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This was designed as a gift for a very special couple. I originally designed the plaque to be hung in a window, but later decided to make it bottom edge lit with LED's. The LED light string is one that is readily available and inexpensive.   
The base is designed to hold a 3mm thick, 3" X 5" acrylic etching.   
The plaque is a cut at 3"x5".   
By changing the quoted text, this can be used for many different occasions and/or awards.

Using the CDR file, etch and cut the plaque. Print the base pieces. Mine were printed at .2/layer in PLA. The holed strip is to hold the prewired LED's. I used hot glue to hold them in place. The place the LED strip into the base with the LED's facing toward the narrow slit. I purchase my lights from http://www.lightsforalloccasions.com, but they can be found in most hobby shops if you are not up for making your own. I keep a supply on hand for making wine bottle lamps. I then hot glued the lamp bar inside of the base to keep it secure. Slide the 3X5 Plaque into the top and turn on the LEDs

The handle for the dip stick on my Miata was broken and it always bugged me. This made for a quick/nice fix.

The STL file has the part standing on end, but it's much easier to print it laying flat on the bed. Lay it down, copy it over to print two. Then glue the two halves together. I used some gorilla glue I had laying around . Then just drill the solid base whatever size you may need to fit over your dip stick. 100% infill will probably work best.
